awd_titl_txt: The effect of variable input on children's acquisition of null subjects
awd_abstract_narration:
Language is essential to almost every aspect of our lives and it is absolutely central to learning in school. The goal of first language acquisition research is to determine how children acquire their native language given the linguistic input to which they are exposed. Research has shown that children do not just imitate word-for-word their input; instead, they produce forms not found in their parents' speech, such as "He eat-ed it" or "I'm hang onto-ing it." Moreover, the linguistic input to which children are exposed is quite complex, as utterances do not always match their underlying representation. For example, in sentences like "Do you want to go?" speakers variably omit the first two words, producing: "You wanna go?", "wanna go?", depending on social context. This project examines the impact of this latter sort of variable input on the acquisition of language in children. 

The empirical domain of this project is the acquisition of properties related to--what has traditionally been called--the Null Subject Parameter in two varieties of Spanish: Dominican Spanish (DS) and Chilean Spanish (ChS). While ChS shows properties of a null subject language, DS displays a number of syntactic properties that are infrequent in other non-Caribbean varieties of Spanish, including variable usage of overt expletive subjects, higher use of overt pronominal subjects in contexts of topic continuity, and variable usage of subject-verb (non)inversion in interrogatives. By comparing acquisition patterns in children exposed to two varieties of the same language, we can compare acquisition of specific grammatical structures in the context of two input types (e.g. consistent input v. variable input) while holding other properties of the language constant. 

This project will collect 120 hours of naturalistic speech between DS caregivers and their children while they play and read together and 40 hours of Dominican adult-to-adult speech. Audio-recordings and transcriptions will be archived on the CHILDES database (http://childes.psy.cmu.edu) for use by future researchers and will provide much needed data on language development in children acquiring non-mainstream dialects of Spanish, which is important in the context of standardized testing, early education, and clinical intervention in the case of speech disorders. This project will also provide international research experience to both graduate and undergraduate students, who will collect data in the Dominican Republic.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report – NSF Award # 1322763

 

Project Title: The effect of variable input on children's acquisition of null subjects

Recipient Organization: Penn State University

Project/Grant Period: 09/01/2018 to 02/28/2019

PI: Karen Miller

This project addressed the question of how children acquire their native language based on the language input to which they are exposed. To address this question, the project investigated acquisition of grammatical morphology and syntactic structures in the context of different input types. Input type refers to whether a linguistic form appears consistently or variably in the input to children. The empirical domain of this project was the acquisition of properties related to (what has traditionally been called in linguistics) the Null Subject Parameter (NSP) in two varieties of Spanish: Dominican Spanish (DS) and Chilean Spanish (ChS). These properties include: null subjects, null expletives, subject-verb inversion in interrogatives, and rich verbal morphology. While ChS shows properties of a null subject language (NSL), DS displays a number of syntactic properties that are infrequent or unattested in other non- Caribbean varieties of Spanish, among these properties is variable usage of overt expletive subjects, higher use of overt pronominal subjects, and variable usage of subject-verb (non)inversion in interrogatives. Comparing the acquisition of null expletives, null/overt pronominal subjects, and subject- verb inversion in these two varieties of Spanish provides a testing ground for various hypotheses about the ways in which the child learner acquires language. By comparing acquisition patterns of children exposed to two varieties of the same language, we can compare acquisition of specific grammatical structures in the context of two input types (e.g. consistent v. variable) while holding other properties of the language constant. 

This project contributes approximately 200 hours of audio recordings and transcribed speech, which will be made available to other researchers via a public database. Forty Dominican Spanish-speaking child-caregiver dyads were recorded while they played together in four recording sessions of an hour each session. This provides data on child-directed speech. In addition, the caregiver participated in a fifth recording session where they talked with another adult. This provided samples of adult-to-adult speech from the same caregiver. Chilean child and caregiver data were collected under a previous grant and was available for comparison. 

It is often difficult to generalize about acquisition rates across dialects because of differences in experimental design and methods in the research carried out. To our knowledge this project is one of the few studies that examines how the input affects production and comprehension of syntax across dialects and age groups in a restricted domain, allowing for a careful comparison between production and comprehension behavior. Since variation is the norm in natural language, we believe that this project informs not only other studies on the acquisition of variation, but it also informs acquisition research, more generally. Moreover, understanding the role of variation in acquisition can inform speech pathologists when designing dialect sensitive tests and working with young children and also early childhood educators who make decisions about language use inside the classroom. Our results will inform both psycholinguists and computational linguists who are interested in modeling language acquisition and change, especially since recordings and transcriptions of the production data will be made available.

 


Last Modified: 03/20/2019
Modified by: Karen L Miller
